metadata.case_name: Appellants (promoted employees) v. State of Andhra Pradesh

facts.text: In V. Jagannadha Rao and Ors. v. State of Andhra Pradesh and Ors. (2001) 10 SCC 401, a three-Judge Bench held that Special Rules framed by Governor under proviso to Article 309 permitting appointment by transfer to higher category based on seniority-cum-efficiency were violative of para 5(2) of Presidential Order under Article 371-D.

Challenge in Jagannadha Rao arose from GOMs No.72 dated 25th February, 1986 and GOMs No.117 dated 28th May, 1986 making UDCs in Labour Department and Factories and Boilers Department eligible for recruitment by transfer to Assistant Inspector of Labour and Assistant Inspector of Factories.

Tribunal in Jagannadha Rao declared impugned Rules violative of paras 3 and 5 of Presidential Order; view upheld by Supreme Court, overruling State of Andhra Pradesh v. V. Sadanandam (1989 Supp (1) SCC 574) and Govt. of A.P. v. B. Satyanarayana Rao (2000) 4 SCC 262.

Present case relates to G.O.M. No.14, Labour Employment Training (Ser. IV) Department, dated 26th November, 1994, amended by G.O.M. No.22 dated 9th May, 1996, providing Senior Assistants and Senior Stenographers in Head Offices eligible for appointment by transfer to post of Assistant Labour Officer, besides those in Subordinate Offices.

Employees approached Andhra Pradesh Administrative Tribunal aggrieved that post of Assistant Labour Officer is zonal post, inclusion of others from outside zone violates paras 3(3) and 5(1) of Presidential Order.

Tribunal partly allowed petitions on 7th March, 2003, struck down GOMs No.14 and 22 to extent providing channel for Senior Assistants/Senior Stenographers in Head Offices and Factories/Boiler Departments, directed no effect to provisions, but prospective only, no disturbance to actions till 7th November, 2001, no reversion of promoted employees.
Writ Petitions No.6163 and 6068 of 2004 filed challenging Tribunal's prospective saving; WP No.16890 of 2006 filed against striking down.
High Court on 9th March, 2007 allowed WP 6163/6068, dismissed WP 16890, set aside Tribunal's prospective application holding doctrine invocable only by Supreme Court.
Review petition WPMP No.3576 of 2010 by appellants (promoted employees not impleaded) dismissed on 3rd November, 2010.
Promoted employees held positions for nearly ten years till review dismissal; State declined to create supernumerary posts.

legal_issues.text: Whether the doctrine of prospective overruling can be invoked to save promotions made under impugned GOMs prior to judgment in V. Jagannadha Rao, despite High Court holding it applicable only by Supreme Court.
Whether GOMs No.14 dated 26.11.1994 as amended by No.22 dated 9.5.1996 violate Presidential Order under Article 371-D by allowing appointment by transfer outside zone cadre.

petitioner_arguments.text: Promoted employees (appellants) were necessary parties to Tribunal and High Court proceedings; absence vitiates judgments.
Doctrine of prospective overruling should be applied to save past promotions as law was in flux till Jagannadha Rao, employees held positions long, reversion unjust.

respondent_arguments.text: Doctrine of prospective overruling invocable only by Supreme Court, not Tribunal or High Court.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Golak Nath v. State of Punjab AIR 1967 SC 1643

respondent_arguments.text: Promoted employees took calculated risk by opting for out-of-cadre posts.

court_reasoning.text: Doctrine of prospective overruling originates in US, first applied in India in Golak Nath; invocable only by Supreme Court under Constitution matters, moulds relief per justice.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Supreme Court can invoke it even if lower courts cannot.

court_reasoning.text: Law in flux till Jagannadha Rao (7.11.2001); promotions before that valid as per prior precedents; non-impleadment of appointees; long tenure (10 years); reversion cascadingly unjust.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Invoke prospective overruling to save pre-7.11.2001 promotions.

court_reasoning.text: Present GOMs different from Jagannadha Rao but similar violation; no impediment to applying doctrine here.

holdings.text: Doctrine of prospective overruling applied; promotions under impugned GOMs prior to 7th November, 2001 protected, no reversion.
Impugned GOMs violative of Presidential Order under Article 371-D, but striking down prospective.

precedents_cited.case_name: V. Jagannadha Rao and Ors. v. State of Andhra Pradesh and Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Held rules violative of Presidential Order para 5(2); date 7.11.2001 benchmark for prospective overruling.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Andhra Pradesh and Anr. v. V. Sadanandam and Ors.
Govt. of A.P. and Anr. v. B. Satyanarayana Rao Dead by Lrs. and Ors.
C. Golak Nath Ors. v. State of Punjab Anr.
precedents_cited.relevance: First invocation of prospective overruling in India; parameters laid down.

precedents_cited.case_name: India Cement Ltd. Ors. v. State of Tamil Nadu Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Applied prospective overruling to deny refunds.

precedents_cited.case_name: Orissa Cement Ltd. v. State of Orissa Ors.
Union of India Ors. v. Mohd. Ramzan Khan
precedents_cited.relevance: Prospective declaration on enquiry report copy.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ashok Kumar Gupta Anr. v. State of U.P. Ors.
M/s Somaiya Organics (India) Ltd. etc. etc. v. State of U.P. Anr.
Kailash Chand Sharma v. State of Rajasthan Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Applied prospective overruling where law in flux, non-impleadment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Managing Director, ECIL Hyderabad v. B. Karunakar
precedents_cited.relevance: Illustrative of prospective overruling in flux.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Proviso to Art 309 rules subordinate to Presidential Order under Art 371-D(10); Art 142 enables prospective overruling.

statutes_cited.name: Andhra Pradesh Public Employment (Organisation of Local Cadres and Regulation of Direct Recruitment) Order, 1975
statutes_cited.relevance: Local cadre unit for recruitment/promotion/transfer; para 5(2) limited transfers, not promotions; violated by impugned GOMs.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed appeals, upheld Tribunal's striking down of GOMs No.14/22 as violative but applied doctrine of prospective overruling to protect promotions made before 7th November, 2001, preventing reversion; no supernumerary posts needed.
outcome.relief_granted: Past promotions saved; no reversion to parent cadre.

key_quotes.text: "The doctrine of prospective overruling can be invoked only in matters arising under our Constitution... only by the highest court of the country, i.e., the Supreme Court."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Reversion of the petitioners to their parent cadre is therefore bound to have a cascading effect, prejudicing even those who are not parties before us."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justification for prospective overruling to avoid injustice.

key_quotes.text: "We find that para 5(2) of the Presidential Order speaks of transfer and not of promotion."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding from Jagannadha Rao distinguishing transfer from promotion.
